text: ZAIN. Remember the word unto thy servant, upon which thou hast caused me to hope.
text_kjv: ZAIN. Remember the word unto thy servant, upon which thou hast caused me to hope.
text_niv: ז ZayinRemember your word to your servant,for you have given me hope.
text_esv: Remember your word to your servant, in which you have made me hope.
text_nlt: Remember your promise to me;it is my only hope.
text_msg: Remember what you said to me, your servant—I hang on to these words for dear life!
text_nasb: Remember the word to Your servant, In which You have made me hope.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem, meaning each section is dedicated to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Each of the 22 sections (corresponding to the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet) contains eight verses, all focusing on the importance and blessings of God's Word, the Torah. 'Zain' is the seventh letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Understanding this structure helps us appreciate the deliberate and comprehensive nature of the Psalmist's devotion to God's law. The Psalmist likely lived during a time when adherence to God’s Law was challenging, perhaps during a period of exile or foreign oppression. The emphasis on remembering God's word suggests a conscious effort to maintain faith and identity in the face of adversity. The concept of a 'servant' of God (thy servant) was a common descriptor of faithful individuals within the covenant relationship with Yahweh. This signifies humility, obedience, and a complete dependence on God. The act of 'remembering' in the Hebrew mind was not simply recalling information but actively considering and applying it to one's life. This remembering involved meditation, internalization, and practical application of God’s commandments. The phrase 'caused me to hope' indicates that the promise of God, rooted in His word, provided a foundation for future expectation. This hope wasn't a passive wish but an active, confident trust in God's faithfulness to fulfill His promises.
meaning: This verse is a powerful plea for God to actively remember His promises to the Psalmist. The Psalmist isn't just asking God to recall something He might have forgotten; rather, he's imploring God to act upon the promises He has already made. The phrase 'the word unto thy servant' refers to the specific promises and covenantal agreements God has made with His people, particularly those pertaining to the Psalmist himself. This verse emphasizes the personal relationship between the Psalmist and God. The Psalmist approaches God not as a distant deity, but as a personal servant relying on his Master's grace and faithfulness. The 'hope' mentioned isn't just wishful thinking but a confident expectation rooted in God's character and proven faithfulness. This hope is not self-generated but 'caused' by God Himself through His word. God's word, therefore, is the source and foundation of the Psalmist's hope. The Psalmist understands that God is faithful to His word and that He will not abandon those who trust in Him. The verse implicitly acknowledges God's sovereignty and power to fulfill His promises. By appealing to God to 'remember,' the Psalmist acknowledges God's ability to act on his behalf. The verse highlights the importance of grounding our hope in God's word rather than in our own abilities or circumstances. True hope comes from knowing God's promises and trusting in His faithfulness to fulfill them.
application: In our modern lives, this verse offers a powerful reminder to anchor our hope in God's promises. We face daily challenges that can easily lead to discouragement and despair. Remembering God's word, and the promises it holds, is crucial for maintaining hope and resilience. First, actively engage with Scripture. This isn't just about reading the Bible but about meditating on it, memorizing key verses, and understanding their context and meaning. Identify specific promises in Scripture that apply to your situation. For example, if you're facing financial hardship, remember God's promise to provide for those who trust in Him (Philippians 4:19). If you're struggling with anxiety, recall His promise of peace that surpasses understanding (Philippians 4:7). Secondly, cultivate a prayer life centered on God's word. Like the Psalmist, plead with God to remember His promises. Remind Him of His faithfulness throughout history and ask Him to act on your behalf according to His will. Don't be afraid to be specific in your prayers, referencing particular promises relevant to your needs. Thirdly, share your struggles and your hope with other believers. Encouragement and accountability from a supportive community can strengthen your faith and help you stay grounded in God's word. Fourthly, actively look for evidence of God's faithfulness in your life. Reflect on past experiences where God has demonstrated His love, power, and provision. This will reinforce your trust in His ability to fulfill His promises in the present and future. Finally, remember that hope is not passive. It requires active faith and obedience to God's word. Trusting in God's promises doesn't mean we sit back and do nothing. It means we actively seek to live according to His will, knowing that He will guide and empower us to fulfill His purpose for our lives.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you as your servant, acknowledging my dependence on your grace and faithfulness. I ask you to remember the word you have spoken, the promises you have made to me. My heart is often burdened with anxieties and uncertainties, and I long to anchor my hope in your unfailing love. Remind me of your promises to provide, to protect, and to never leave me. Grant me the wisdom to understand your word and the strength to apply it to my life. Cause me to hope in you, knowing that you are faithful to fulfill all your promises. Thank you for being a God who hears and answers prayer. In Jesus' name, Amen.
